user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_:
```c
static int
mhd_tool_get_sys_cpu_count_sysctl_fallback_ (void)
{
  int ret = -1;
  /* Do not use sysctl() function on GNU/Linux even if
     sysctl() is available */
#ifndef __linux__
#ifdef HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    /* FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, Darwin (and others?): The number of CPUs */
    if ((0 != sysctlbyname ("hw.ncpu", &ret, &value_size,
                            NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTLBYNAME */
#if defined(HAVE_SYSCTL) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_CTL_HW) && \
  defined(HAS_DECL_HW_NCPU)
  if (0 >= ret)
  {
    /* FreeBSD, OpenBSD, NetBSD, Darwin (and others?): The number of CPUs */
    int mib[2] = {CTL_HW, HW_NCPU};
    size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);
    if ((0 != sysctl (mib, 2, &ret, &value_size, NULL, 0))
        || (sizeof (ret) != value_size))
      ret = -1;
  }
#endif /* HAVE_SYSCTL && HAS_DECL_CTL_HW && HAS_DECL_HW_NCPU */
#endif /* ! __linux__ */
  if (0 >= ret)
    return -1;
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. Specifically:

- There are no GCC/MSVC-specific keywords or constructs such as __attribute__, __asm__, __inline__, __builtin_*, __typeof__, statement-expressions ({ ... }), nested functions, or other documented compiler extensions.
- Preprocessor constructs (#ifndef, #if defined(...), backslash line continuation) are standard C preprocessor features, not compiler extensions.
- The use of predefined implementation macros such as __linux__ is an implementation-defined macro provided by compilers, not a language extension construct in the source code itself (and is commonly used in portable conditional compilation).
- Variable declarations inside blocks (e.g. size_t value_size = sizeof (ret);) and array initialization (int mib[2] = {CTL_HW, HW_NCPU};) are standard C (C99 and later). They are not compiler extensions per se; if a particular toolchain lacks C99 support that would be a configuration issue rather than an explicit use of a documented compiler extension.
- Calls to sysctlbyname/sysctl are platform/library APIs, not language extensions.

Because none of the above constructs are compiler-documented language extensions, there are no suspicious fragments to report for Rule 1.2.
